subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-1386064241-1241989167=:3843
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level comparison.=A0 An audio fil=
e is just a file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an audio player.=A0=
 Two files with the exact same contents, whether they are audio or image or=
 a dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each other.=A0 That is, i=
f I copied the contents of one to a new file, and the contents of the other=
 to a new file, and asked you which file each came from, there would be no =
way to tell.=A0 Even the audio player could not tell.=A0 The data is identi=
cal, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be identical.

Yes I did =
listen to the results, but that is not the best test (they sounded identica=
l, but that is a subjective opinion).=A0 The real test is compring the cont=
ents.=A0 Identical contents means indentical data, means identical audio.

=
It is probably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do =
lossy audio compression.=A0 My tests show my setup does not.=A0 If you'd li=
ke me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy c=
ompression from an attachment would be very unusual.

myself. Jon from this li=
st is the one who originally told me about it.=A0I

appening to a few other people.=A0After=A0my

lked to a computer professional, and he told me 
that you can experience lo=
ss in attached files.
=A0
I don't know if you would be able to tell 
loss o=
f quality in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. Just because the 
d=
ata has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect.
=A0
Did you list=
en to the before and=A0after 
results?
=A0
Jon-Please relay your experience=
 with the 
loss of quality on emailed files.
=A0
=A0

  ----- Original Mess=
age ----- 
  From:

ay 10, 2009 2:38 PM

  =

  
  
    
    
      I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I ju=
st 
        did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and=
 back, 
        once allowing compression, and once turning it off.=A0=A0 I=
 was 
        able to verify that one was compressed and one was not, by ch=
ecking the 
        sizes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came back t=
o MSN, I then did 
        a bit-level comparison of the original, and the =
ones sent around 
        email.=A0 They were all identical, which indicate=
s lossless 
        compression.

If you have a file you'd like me to test =
for you, 
        let me know.=A0 But I wouldn't take someone's word for ho=
w your 
        server's work, without testing them yourself.

arch. com> 
        wrote:

        
From: 
          April Abercrombie

To:

=
          For executables, you may be right. 
          However, for wav fi=
les, the compression during email is not loss less. 
          
          =
=A0
          I used to think as you do, in that 
          the emailed att=
achment=A0of a wav file would not loose anything. 
          After a length=
y discourse with another member here, I learned that I 
          was wrong=
. The reason why=A0I did not realize it in the first place 
          is th=
at when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it 
          =
in very small segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease 
   =
       of transfer. But because of this, I had not experienced any noticeab=
le 
          loss.
          =A0
          Now it may be in some cases, 
 =
         depending on the servers or what have you that the file goes throu=
gh, 
          that the loss may be less or more. But once the attachment i=
s 
          downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been found to be less then 
=
          the original wav.
          =A0
          Again though you can on=
ly really 
          tell when the=A0wav file is large.
          =A0
     =
     ----- Original Message ----- 
          
            From: 
          =
  Rj 
            To: 
            EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
            .com 
 =
           Sent: 
            Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
            Subj=
ect: 
            Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
            

        =
    
            
            
              
              
              =
  The kind of compression that occurs during an 
                  email at=
tachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly 
                  wi=
thout losing information.=A0 For example, if I had a 
                  pro=
gram in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it could 
              =
    compress it.=A0 But if it lost even one bit, the resulting 
           =
       exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
     =
             the other side.

This kind of compression does things 
       =
           like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing 
   =
               them with a token.=A0 A rough example would be if it found 
=
                  "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all=
 the 
                  occurances with say $HN1.=A0 And also write a littl=
e 
                  dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy =

                  Neighbor".

When the file gets to its destination it can=
 
                  be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replace=
d with 
                  "Howdy Neighbor".=A0 So it was compressed (instea=
d of 14 
                  characters each, it only needed 4, plus the dict=
ionary), but 
                  lost no data.

Some formats, like jpeg and =
mp3. are not 
                  lossless.=A0 Depending on the level of comp=
ression, some 
                  level of data is lost, and so cannot be re=
covered or 
                  reconstructed later.

Rick

=
                    Another 
                    thing:
                   =
 =A0
                    I recently found this 
                    out. Wh=
en you email a file, if it is not saved as a 
                    compresse=
d format, the email filtering process will actually 
                    co=
mpress the file automatically.
                    =A0
                    =
So even if you have 
                    attached a wav. file, it will loos=
e resolution over the 
                    email process. It will not sound=
 exactly the same as the 
                    original wav. file. How much =
it differs depends on the size 
                    of the file you are att=
aching. If it is a very=A0large 
                    file, it will sound mu=
ch different.
                    =A0
                    The only exceptio=
n to 
                    this is if the wav. file is small enough that the=
 filtering 
                    process will ignore it. It has to be pretty=
 small though, 
                    like under 1=A0MB (I am not exactly sur=
e of the 
                    threshold).
                    =A0
         =
           The best way to share 
                    files over the intern=
et=A0if you want them as close to 
                    the original as poss=
ible is to upload them directly to a 
                    website.
        =
            =A0
                    
                      ----- 
         =
             Original Message ----- 
                      From: 
         =
             Rj 
                      To: 
                      EVP-ITC@y=
ahoogroups .com 
                      Sent: 
                      Sunday,=
 May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                      Subject: 
                    =
  Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                      

              =
        
                      
                      
                    =
    
                        
                          
Pixelization doesn=
't clean-up the 
                            data: it replaces it.=A0 Imagi=
ne taking a picture 
                            of a field of flowers, and=
 beginning to add levels 
                            or pixelization to th=
e picture.=A0 Soon, you 
                            would not be able to t=
ell there were flowers there 
                            at all.=A0 You wo=
uld see a lot of colored 
                            blocks.

Or in the ot=
her direction, imagine 
                            you are looking at a co=
mpetely randomize bunch of 
                            pixes on your scree=
n: a complete screen of truely 
                            random static s=
now.=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
                            while, you wo=
uld again start to see colored 
                            blocks.

What's=
 happening is that it is 
                            processing an area of=
 the image, taking (for 
                            instance) the average =
value of that entire area, and 
                            replacing all t=
he blocks in that area with the 
                            average.=A0 In=
 video processing, this would 
                            result in a fiel=
d of multi-colored flowers being 
                            replaced by, =
for instance, a big greyish-bluish 
                            block, with=
 no resemblance to flowers.=A0 In the 
                            noise ex=
ample, it maybe replace all the random 
                            pixels =
with another big greyish-bluish block.=A0 
                            If y=
ou did not know beforehand what the original 
                            p=
icture was, you couldn't tell whether your 
                            pix=
elized image was really a field of flowers, a 
                            =
chevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of 
                         =
   pixels.

It works the same with the sound 
                            f=
iles.=A0 Taking something as complex as speech, 
                          =
  and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses 
                   =
         the speech the farther you go, until you head 
                   =
         strange fluctuating square waves.=A0 Doing the 
                  =
          same to random static will eventually produce the 
              =
              same thing.=A0 And random fluctuating square 
               =
             waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you 
        =
                    could have fun sharing with each other what you 
      =
                      thing they 'sound like'.

    As far as pixelization of non sounds/white

             =
                   Be a bit careful of formats like 
                      =
          mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
                =
                sounds though.=A0=A0 While some formats 
                  =
              (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
           =
                     way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
      =
                          the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic =

                                details.=A0 This may not be a big deal in =

                                music, where the audio is fairly clear to =
begin 
                                with.=A0 But with sound sources with=
 a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this can not =
only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixelize=
 non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make th=
em start to sound like 
                                speech.

So mp3 mig=
ht be good for sharing 
                                the data, once you'=
ve already formed an opinion 
                                based on an a=
nalysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
                                mp3 is not=
 good as a medium for analysis.=A0 
                                It can =
lead to many false positives and 
                                misinterp=
retations.

    the emailed attachment of a wav file would not loose anything. 
  =
        After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I learned that =
I 
          was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the fir=
st place 
          is that when I would email a wav file, I would intentio=
nally keep it 
          in very small segments, to keep file size down. Th=
is was just for ease 
          of transfer. But because of this, I had not=
 experienced any noticeable 
          loss.</font></div>
          <div><f=
ont face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
          <div><font=
 face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">Now it may be in some cases, 
          dep=
ending on the servers or what have you that the file goes through, 
       =
   that the loss may be less or more. But once the attachment is 
         =
 downloaded, the quality has been found to be less then 
   =
       the original wav.</font></div>
          <div><font face=3D"Myriad P=
ro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
          <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro"=
 size=3D"2">Again though you can only really 
          tell when the =
wav file is large.</font></div>
          <div> </div>

                <=
td valign=3D"top">The kind of compression that occurs during an 
          =
        email attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly 
    =
              without losing information.  For example, if I had a 
  =
                program in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it co=
uld 
                  compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, the =
resulting 
                  exe file would not execute again after it was =
uncompressed on 
                  the other side.<br><br>This kind of comp=
ression does things 
                  like looking for common patterns in =
the file, and replacing 
                  them with a token.  A rough=
 example would be if it found 
                  "Howdy Neighbor" in a file=
 20 times, it could replace all the 
                  occurances with say =
$HN1.  And also write a little 
                  dictionary in there =
someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy 
                  Neighbor".<br><br>When=
 the file gets to its destination it can 
                  be uncompressed=
, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with 
                  "Howdy Ne=
ighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 
                  chara=
cters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but 
                  =
lost no data.<br><br>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not 
            =
      lossless.  Depending on the level of compression, some 
        =
          level of data is lost, and so cannot be recovered or 
           =
       reconstructed later.<br><br>Rick<br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
    =
              5/10/09, April Abercrombie <i><april@abercrombiegh 
      =
            ostresearch. com></i></b> wrote:<br>
                  <bloc=
kquote style=3D"border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From: 
      =
              April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
     =
               com><br>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading 
          =
          rules<br>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<br>Date: Sunday, May 
     =
               10, 2009, 10:26 AM<br><br>
                    <div id=3D"yi=
v819860743">
                    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
                   =
 <p></p>
                    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">Anot=
her 
                    thing:</font></div>
                    <div><font=
 face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
                    <di=
v><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">I recently found this 
             =
       out. When you email a file, if it is not saved as a 
               =
     compressed format, the email filtering process will actually 
        =
            compress the file automatically.</font></div>
                 =
   <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
          =
          <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">So even if you have 
  =
                  attached a wav. file, it will loose resolution over the 
=

e 
                    original wav. file. How much it differs depends on t=
he size 
                    of the file you are attaching. If it is a very=
 large 
                    file, it will sound much different.</font>=
</div>
                    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font=
> </div>
                    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"=
>The only exception to 
                    this is if the wav. file is sma=
ll enough that the filtering 
                    process will ignore it. I=
t has to be pretty small though, 
                    like under 1 MB =
(I am not exactly sure of the 
                    threshold).</font></div>=

                    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font>&nbsp=
;</div>
                    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">The b=
est way to share 
                    files over the internet if you w=
ant them as close to 
                    the original as possible is to up=
load them directly to a 
                    website.</font></div>

                        <tr>
                          <=
td valign=3D"top"><br>Pixelization doesn't clean-up the 
                  =
          data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture 
           =
                 of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels 
      =
                      or pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you 
    =
                        would not be able to tell there were flowers there =

                            at all.  You would see a lot of colored 
=
                            blocks.<br><br>Or in the other direction, imagi=
ne 
                            you are looking at a competely randomize bu=
nch of 
                            pixes on your screen: a complete screen=
 of truely 
                            random static snow.  Pixelizin=
g this, after a 
                            while, you would again start t=
o see colored 
                            blocks.<br><br>What's happening =
is that it is 
                            processing an area of the image,=
 taking (for 
                            instance) the average value of th=
at entire area, and 
                            replacing all the blocks i=
n that area with the 
                            average.  In video p=
rocessing, this would 
                            result in a field of mul=
ti-colored flowers being 
                            replaced by, for inst=
ance, a big greyish-bluish 
                            block, with no rese=
mblance to flowers.  In the 
                            noise example=
, it maybe replace all the random 
                            pixels with =
another big greyish-bluish block.  
                            If you=
 did not know beforehand what the original 
                            pic=
ture was, you couldn't tell whether your 
                            pixel=
ized image was really a field of flowers, a 
                            ch=
evy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of 
                           =
 pixels.<br><br>It works the same with the sound 
                         =
   files.  Taking something as complex as speech, 
                   =
         and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses 
            =
                the speech the farther you go, until you head 
            =
                strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the 
        =
                    same to random static will eventually produce the 
    =
                        same thing.  And random fluctuating square 
  =
                          waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, =
you 
                            could have fun sharing with each other wha=
t you 
                            thing they 'sound like'.<br><br><br><br>=
<br><br>---

                                <td valign=
=3D"top">Be a bit careful of formats like 
                                =
mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
                          =
      sounds though.   While some formats 
                      =
          (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
               =
                 way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
          =
                      the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
   =
                             details.  This may not be a big deal in 
=
                                music, where the audio is fairly clear to b=
egin 
                                with.  But with sound sources wi=
th a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this can no=
t only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixeli=
ze non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make =
them start to sound like 
                                speech.<br><br>So=
 mp3 might be good for sharing 
                                the data, o=
nce you've already formed an opinion 
                                based=
 on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
                               =
 mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  
                         =
       It can lead to many false positives and 
                           =
     misinterpretations.<br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
                           =
     5/10/09, Misty Dawn <i><bulletbabea@ 
                             =
   yahoo.com></i></b> wrote:<br>
